snippet.title: A fierce battle is on to release secret letters to the Queen about the dismissal of Gough Whitlam
snippet.content:
Gough Whitlam - Giant of Australian politics 3:39
Look back at tumultuous political career of Australia's 21st Prime Minister, Edward Gough Whitlam.
October 22nd 2014 3 years ago /display/newscorpaustralia.com/Web/NewsNetwork/Network News/National/
Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh Prince Philip with Governor-General Sir John Kerr during a royal tour of Australia in 1977.
Staff writerNews Corp Australia Network
Share
A BATTLE is under way in the Federal Court to release secret correspondence with the Queen about the extraordinary dismissal of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam in 1975. Mystery surrounds how much the monarch knew in the lead up to the move by Sir John Kerr, who in his capacity as Governor-General during a constitutional crisis. A landmark case before the courts seeks to have the documents dubbed "the palace letters" made public - a move being fiercely resisted by the National Archives. Their contents signify the final elusive piece of the puzzle that is , those fighting to see them believe.
In this November 7, 2005 file photo, former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam holds up the original copy of his dismissal letter he received from then Governor-General Sir John Kerr. Picture: APSource:AP So closely guarded is the correspondence with the Queen that they were locked in a safe for three years after the November 11 sacking of Mr Whitlam, before being copied by hand "in the dead of night" and squirrelled away by Sir Kerr's official secretary in 1978. The original letters have remained in the "care and custody" of the National Archives since and aren't due for sanctioned disclosure until 2027. And even then, there's a chance their release could be blocked.
Historian Jenny Hocking arrives at the Federal Court, fighting the National Archives to release letters between Queen Elizabeth and her former representative, Governor-General Sir John Kerr. Picture: APSource:AP
Gough Whitlam with his wife Margaret and Governor-General John Kerr, pictured the month before the dismissal.Source:News Corp Australia Lawyers representing the National Archive argued that governors-general act "personally and independently" of the government of the day and shouldn't be subject to normal public scrutiny.
The late Mr Whitlam's son Anthony, a QC representing academic and Whitlam biographer, Professor Jenny Hocking in the bid to reveal "the final piece of the puzzle" of the dismissal, appeared in court yesterday. "Mr Whitlam mentioned a conversation - relayed in an extract of one of Kerr's letters accidentally released by the National Archives - where his father told Kerr the crisis could be resolved by a rush to the phone by both men seeking to have the Queen sack the other," The Australian . But the National Archives insisted the letters were "personal records" rather than official records.
The case has been adjourned until September.
